quote: This leads to a quantum machine learning framework where classical information embedded in quantum bits can take advantage of quantum phenomena and increased expressibility for a potential reduction in network size and training time on quantum hardware.
A possible benefit in addressing such problems with quantum networks is an increased expressibility of quantum bits over classical bits.
the classical binary representation is replaced with a continuous space of possible superposition states.
The coefficients a and b are also used to describe the probability of measuring the state associated with that coefficient.
Instead of acting on bits, these components act on quantum bits, or qubits, which are binary representations of quantum states in a 2-state system.
Thus, similarly, our quantum logic gates must be able to act not only on binary states, but also on any superposition of binary states.
The fundamental difference in how this binary state behaves is again the notion of superposition.
The Hadamard gate is typically used in circuits at the very beginning to generate a uniform superposition state that will be leveraged by the rest of the circuit.
One can quickly see that the richness of the quantum description yields many more usable operations in comparison to the classical case.
The feature of having a much larger (uncountably infinite) gate set is much more pronounced with larger multi-qubit operators.

A major challenge in quantum computing is finding codes that reduce the necessary number of qubits to achieve a logical qubit, and building a large enough quantum computer with enough fault tolerance to be able to perform useful operations on these logical qubits.
Coupled to this issue is that circuits of increasing numbers of qubits suffer from cross-talk errors, which is when qubits in different channels become undesirably entangled to each other.
The per-layer loss gradient, often called the local gradient, is computed backwards across layers of the network.
Since quantum gate operations must be unitary and reversible, the total number of qubits is conserved throughout the circuit.
Quantum machine learning is a new and emerging sub-field of quantum computing that combines two specialized fields into one.
